Posts.Content: allmans wrote: Hello, I'm sorry for all of my questions but this is all new to me.  My sis goes for her second TAC treatment tomorrow.  She has mets to lungs and an open wound.  My question is this:  before treatment she was extremely weak, then she was feeling so good for the past two weeks, which was after her first chemo, now all of a sudden she is feeling very weak again.  Does this happen in between treatments, does the cancer start to grow again?  I'm confused. Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: weakness between treatments allmans LoriFL

Posts.Content: allmans wrote: Hello, I can't seem to find anyone who has what my sister has.  Apparently it's rare.  She has what's called a fungating mass on her breast, which is basically a huge open infected wound.  She's currently receiving chemo and after that mastectomy may be an option.  There is a good chance she can't have a mastectomy because the wound is so deep into the chest wall that if they remove it, she would be left with a gaping hole.  Has anyone experienced this or know of anyone who has?  I'm afraid that if she cant have it removed her life will become a pure living hell.  The wound smells, so she doesn't want to be around people. Posts.Title: mastectomy with an ulcerated wound allmans cornflakegirl

Posts.Content: Mar 11, 2008 08:56AM allmans wrote: Hello Anne, I don't know about the hyperbarics, but she went for a second opinion at Sloan Kettering yesterday, and they basically said what I stated above.  I know it's hard to believe that in todays day and age nothing can be done for this.  We don't know for sure yet, need to finish chemo first.

Posts.Content: Aug 26, 2008 08:24AM allmans wrote: I figure hospice will be the next step.  For the short term, dr. said her white count was very low and she may have picked up colitis in the hospital.  So I'm still holding onto some hope.  LuAnn I read somewhere that you have seen people close to death that make a comeback.  I'm holding onto that!
Posts.Title: My sister allmans LuAnnH

Posts.Content: Aug 25, 2008 03:37PM allmans wrote: thanks for all your kind words.  My sister is going back into the hospital as we speak.  the visiting nurse said her oxygen level is very low, she hasn't eaten in about 3 days and she has horrible diarrhea, which she said may be a sign of kidney failure and of course she is bedridden.  does this sound like the end?
Posts.Title: My sister allmans LuAnnH

Posts.Content: allmans wrote: Hi all, I am resigning myself to the fact that my sister won't be around much longer.  She came home from the hospital this past week after spending 6 weeks there.  I think they knew to send her home and let her live her last few weeks in peace.  I'm almost certain they will stop the chemo.  She can barely eat, is extremely weak and can't do much of anything except sleep.  Can't imagine her bouncing back.  I just don't understand, I thought that when they did the mastectomy and got rid of the huge tumor she would start to feel a little better, at least a little better.  She has lung and liver mets, but I,m sure it must be elsewhere also.  She must be all of 75 lbs.  Since diagnosis she has had nothing but misery.  This truly is the most horrible of diseases. Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: My sister allmans LuAnnH

Posts.Content: Aug 30, 2008 06:19PM allmans wrote: Well my sister went to rehab for one day and is now back in the hospital.  She is filled with fluid.   Does the cancer cause all of this or are all of her organs shutting down?  Can she overcome this?  This disease is just ravishing her body.  I don't know if I should pray for God to take her and put her out of her misery or to keep her here and pray for recovery.  I'm losing my faith in miracles.
